    Biden made ‘important’ statement about Taiwan: Marles
    Acting Prime Minister Richard Marles says it is “important” that America has presence in east Asia, following President Joe Biden’s recent remarks about the United States’ willingness to defend Taiwan militarily against China. Mr Biden was asked whether the US would be willing to get its military involved to defend Taiwan during a press briefing before the Quad meeting on Monday, to which he responded: "Yes - it's a commitment we made". When questioned if Australia would respond in the same way if China invaded Taiwan, Mr Marles said the Americans have made an “important statement”, however, he doesn’t think it’s wise to start “commenting on hypotheticals”. “It is important that the Americans have made the statement that they have because what it represents is an American presence in the region which is something which is very much in our national interest,” he told Sky News Australia. “That’s what we want to encourage and that’s why the Quad is important and that’s why it was so important that Anthony Albanese attends the Quad so shortly after the election. “We work very closely with the United States. I think it’s important to not walk down hypothetical paths but it’s also very important to make clear that we stand with the United States, and that we have a very close alliance with the United States.”

    Kwaku Ohene-Frempong, sickle cell expert, dies at 76
    In his native Ghana, Dr Ohene-Frempong set up a pilot program to screen newborns for sickle cell disease in the southern city of Kumasi. This was the first program of its kind in sub-Saharan Africa. In addition to identifying children with the disease, the program referred them to specialist clinics which provided treatments such as antibiotics to prevent infections, routine vaccinations and a drug, hydroxyurea, which can reduce the risk of complications from sickle cell disease.. Kwaku Ohene-Fremong was born on March 13, 1946 in Kukurantumi, Eastern Ghana to Kwasi Adde Ohene and Adwoa Odi Boafo. His father was a cocoa farmer and a prominent member of a royal family.
